abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Construction Industry
            Project for Sri Lanka was successful. Most of the objectives
            were achieved, the impact of the project has been
            significant, sustainability is likely, and both the Borrower
            and the Bank acted satisfactorily. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, planning in the
            construction industry should provide for its inherent
            volatility and include built-in mechanisms for a continuous
            assessment of training needs. Second, planning should take
            cognizance of the need to provide for preliminary
            activities. Third, for future projects, several agencies
            should be required to contribute towards the successful
            implementation of a project. Fourth, every effort should be
            made to implement the recommendations of the National
            Steering Committee's documents in both the public and
            private sectors for maintaining uniformity of standards.
            Fifth, more incentives should be given to local contractors
            for upgrading their knowledge of financial control and
            management and construction technology in order to enable
            them to execute their work efficiently. Lastly, curricula
            and training standards should be constantly reviewed and
            developed to maintain standards of achievement acceptable to
            the construction industry.
